conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C, we need to analyze the process on the given \( p \)-\( V \) diagram.
State B has pressure \( p_B = 0.6p_0 \) and volume \( V_B = V_0 \).
State C has pressure \( p_C = 0.6p_0 \) and volume \( V_C = 0.5V_0 \).

premise: State B has pressure \( p_B = 0.6p_0 \) and volume \( V_B = V_0 \). State C has pressure \( p_C = 0.6p_0 \) and volume \( V_C = 0.5V_0 \).
conclusion: The process from B to C is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
For an isobaric process, the work done \( W \) by the gas is given by: \( W = p \Delta V \) where \( p \) is the constant pressure and \( \Delta V \) is the change in volume.

premise: State B has volume \( V_B = V_0 \). State C has volume \( V_C = 0.5V_0 \).
conclusion: The change in volume \( \Delta V \) from state B to state C is \( \Delta V = V_C - V_B = 0.5V_0 - V_0 = -0.5V_0 \).

premise: The process is isobaric with pressure \( p = 0.6p_0 \) and change in volume \( \Delta V = -0.5V_0 \).
